title: Jean-Jacques Conceição
text:
Jean-Jacques Nzadi da Conceição (born 3 April 1964, in <a href="Kinshasa">Kinshasa</a>), more commonly known as J.J. Conceição or Jean-Jacques, is an Angolan-Portuguese retired professional <a href="basketball">basketball</a> player. A 2.02 m (6'7 "), 100 kg (220 lbs.) <a href="power%20forward%20%28basketball%29">power forward</a>, he represented <a href="Angolan%20national%20basketball%20team">Angola</a> at the <a href="AfroBasket">AfroBasket</a>, where he won a record seven African titles. At the <a href="sports%20club">club</a> level, he won five <a href="Angolan%20Basketball%20League">Angolan League</a> championship titles with <a href="C.D.%20Primeiro%20de%20Agosto%20%28basketball%29">Primeiro de Agosto</a> and four <a href="Angolan%20Basketball%20Cup">Angolan Cups</a>, before moving to <a href="S.L.%20Benfica%20%28basketball%29">Benfica</a> in Portugal, where he won seven <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20League">Portuguese national championships</a> and three <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20Cup">Portuguese Federation Cups</a>. He also went on to play for <a href="CSP%20Limoges">CSP Limoges</a> in France, <a href="Baloncesto%20M%C3%A1laga">Baloncesto Málaga</a> in Spain, and Portugal Telecom in Portugal.
Professional career.
Even though he never played in the <a href="NBA">NBA</a>, Jean-Jacques enjoyed a successful career in Europe, especially in Portugal, where he won 10 <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20League">Portuguese national championships</a> (7 with <a href="S.L.%20Benfica%20%28basketball%29">Benfica</a> and 3 with Portugal Telecom), 7 <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20Cup">Portuguese Federation Cups</a> (5 with Benfica and 2 with Portugal Telecom), 5 <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20Super%20Cup">Portuguese Super Cups</a> (4 with Benfica and 1 with Portugal Telecom), and 6 <a href="Portuguese%20Basketball%20League%20Cup">Portuguese League Cups</a> (all with Benfica).
National team career.
As a member of the senior <a href="Angolan%20national%20basketball%20team">Angolan national team</a>, Conceição won seven <a href="AfroBasket">AfroBasket</a> gold medals, namely in <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201989">1989</a>, <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201992">1992</a>, <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201993">1993</a>, <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201995">1995</a>, <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201999">1999</a>, <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%202001">2001</a>, and <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%202003">2003</a>. He also won silver medals in <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201983">1983</a> and <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201985">1985</a>, and a bronze medal in <a href="FIBA%20Africa%20Championship%201997">1997</a>. 
He also played for his country at the <a href="FIBA%20World%20Cup">FIBA World Cup</a> in <a href="1986%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1986</a>, <a href="1990%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1990</a>, and <a href="1994%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1994</a>. He also played at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympic Games</a> in <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">1992</a>, where he faced the famed <a href="1992%20United%20States%20men%27s%20Olympic%20basketball%20team">Dream Team</a>. The Americans won easily, 116-48, but Conceição led the Angolans with ten points, seven rebounds and two assists.
Post-career.
In 2011, in Antananarivo, within the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of <a href="FIBA%20Africa">FIBA Africa</a>, Jacques was named the <a href="most%20valuable%20player">most valuable player</a> in African basketball history.
On 19 June 2013, Jean-Jacques became a <a href="FIBA%20Hall%20of%20Famer">FIBA Hall of Fame player</a>.

Personal life.
Jean-Jacques Conceição is the father to Angolan-Portuguese basketball player <a href="Jacques%20Concei%C3%A7%C3%A3o">Jacques Conceição</a>.
